() , ? asked the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Foreign Employment and Tourism:
(i) whether he is aware that the Ruhunu Tourist Bureau has started the Madunagala Tourist Project;
(ii) the amount of money that has been spent to construct a building to establish a heart massage (heart revival) centre, using hot water springs in Madunagala; and
(iii) the steps that will be taken to complete the construction of that building as the work of that building has not yet been finished;
(b) Will he also inform this House -
(i) separately, the amount of money that has been spent on the cafeteria, restroom and dining hall that have been constructed in the Madunagala Tourist Zone under this project;
(ii) whether he is aware that the generators at the tourist bungalow which was constructed at a considerable expense are currently out of order and the roof is in a dilapidated condition;
(iii) the amount of money that has been spent to construct the rural bazaar;
(iv) whether he is aware that the bazaar is in ruins by now; and
(v) the steps that will be taken to re-implement that project?
() ( ) ( () - ) (The Hon. (Prof.) Ruwan Ranasinghe - Deputy Minister of Tourism) , , .

CEY-NOR HOUSING SCHEME, BATTICALOA: GRANT OF TITLE
() , ? asked the Minister of Urban Development, Construction and Housing:
(i) whether he is aware that a housing scheme named Cey-Nor Housing Scheme was constructed in the year 1982 in

Kaluwankeni-2 in Eravur Pattu Divisional Secretary's Division of the Batticaloa District; (ii) whether he is aware that the residents of those houses/lands are facing various difficulties in obtaining electricity supply and drinking water supply to those houses/lands as title deeds have not been issued to them for those lands to date; (iii) if so, whether steps will be taken to issue title deeds for those houses/lands; and (iv) the timeframe for granting those title deeds?
( , ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Anura Karunathilaka - Minister of Urban Development, Construction and Housing) , , - - 2 , 1982 - ,. .

SUBSTANDARD COCONUT OIL: PREVENT SUPPLY TO THE
asked the Minister of Trade, Commerce, Food Security and Co-operative Development:
(i) whether the prevalence of substandard coconut oil, which is not suitable for consumption, has been detected in the Sri Lankan market;
(ii) if so, the way such substandard coconut oil is supplied to the market;
(iii) the tactics that are used for it;
(iv) the measures that have been taken to prevent them; and
(v) the reasons for high standard coconut oil not being supplied to the market?
(b) Will he also inform this House the -
(i) problems faced by the owners of small and medium-scale oil mills; and
(ii) solutions that will be given to those problems?
(, , ) ( - , , ) (The Hon. Wasantha Samarasinghe - Minister of Trade, Commerce, Food Security and Cooperative Development) , .

Water Resources Board has requested the University of Peradeniya during the period from 08.11.2024 to 14.01.2025 to study and submit a report on the social, economic and environmental concerns that have emerged due to the salinity barrier constructed across the Nilwala River;

Hon. Deputy Chairman, I would like to say just one last thing. I was not present here when the Hon. Harshana Nanayakkara had mentioned about the former President, that he is a thief and a beggar. I would like to say

something in that regard. At the end of the day, we all must understand one thing. All of you had been voted in and you are sitting in your seats today because people wanted a change. And, people wanted a change not just in terms of administration, but also in terms of the political culture. For the Minister of Justice and National Integration, whom I have a load of respect for and whom I hold in high regard, to call the person who saved this country a beggar and a thief, I think, is highly irrational and he does need to issue an apology.

Apart from that, enough with these shows of showing lists after lists. If something had been done illegally, then take action. If it is not illegal, what is the point in showing a list and just parading it around? Madam, I must condemn what the Hon. Harshana Nanayakkara had spoken about the former President. And, at the end of the day, people will judge you by actions, not by petty insults.

. In fact, we also want the authorities to investigate, in accordance with the law, the activities that have allegedly taken place in our area. We wish to identify, in particular, the forces that are financing, patronizing and orchestrating such activities. The fear of a deep state looms in our minds, too, as it may not be under the Governments control. , deep state . . , .

We do not want another incident where, despite early warnings and cooperation by the Muslim community, the authorities have failed to act in a timely and responsible manner. In fact, there is a prevalent culture of early warning within the Muslim community, which needs to be nurtured and respected.

Question, "That the increased sum of Rs. 24,990,000,000, for Recurrent Expenditure, be inserted in the Schedule" put and agreed to.
Recurrent Expenditure, as amended, ordered to stand part of the Schedule.

Capital Expenditure, as amended, ordered to stand part of the Schedule.

Head 124, Programme 01, Capital Expenditure, ordered to stand part of the Schedule.

Head 124, Programme 02, Capital Expenditure, as amended, ordered to stand part of the Schedule.

. . Question proposed. ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Chairperson of Committees) , . 4 .
SOCIAL IMPACT OF DRUG ADDICTION AMONG YOUTH IN
( ) (The Hon. Rajeevan Jeyachandramoorthy) Hon. Deputy Chairperson of Committees, I move the following Adjournment Motion:

"I move this Adjournment Motion to draw the urgent attention of the House to a serious and alarming issue affecting the Jaffna District, particularly among the youth. The rising problems of drug addiction, illegal consumption, drug smuggling, and gang violence have escalated to critical levels, causing immense harm to our society.
The people of Jaffna, once known for their strong community bonds, are now grappling with severe social and economic instability, mainly due to the widespread abuse of narcotics and
the rise of criminal gangs. This escalating situation has had a detrimental effect on the security and well-being of our citizens, particularly women, children and youth in the area.

Key issues of concern: the situation in Jaffna is severely impacted by rising drug addiction, especially among the youth, with heroin and other illicit substances being consumed widely. This has led to a spike in criminal activities as addicted individuals turn to crime for support, while the lack of rehabilitation centres worsens the issue. Jaffna has also become a hotspot for drug smuggling, fueling gang violence and criminal activities. The increase in gang violence, driven by territorial disputes and drug trafficking, has led to loss of lives and destruction of property. Furthermore, the rise in drug addiction has caused a surge in theft, robbery and violent crimes compromising public safety. Women, girls and schoolchildren are particularly vulnerable, facing harassment, robbery and fear on their way to school due to the presence of gangs and drug addicts in the community."

Madam, I rise today to bring urgent attention to a critical issue that is affecting our youth, especially in the Jaffna District in the Northern Province and the Eastern Province. The growing problems of drug addiction, illegal consumption, drug smuggling and gang violence have reached alarming levels and are causing immense harm to our society.

Jaffna, once known for its strong community values, is now struggling with social and economic instability. The widespread abuse caused by narcotics and the rise of criminal gangs are having a devastating impact on the security and well-being of our citizens, particularly women, children and youth.

The key issues affecting Jaffna are as follows: one, drug addiction. Rising drug addiction, especially among youth, is leading to criminal activities, as individuals turn to crime to support their addiction. Two, lack of rehabilitation centres. The shortage of rehabilitation centres is worsening the problem, leaving many individuals without proper treatment and support. Three, drug smuggling and gang violence. Jaffna has become a hub for drug smuggling, fueling gang violence over territory and control, resulting in deaths and property destruction. Four, crime and public safety. Increased drug addiction has caused a rise in theft, robbery and violent crimes, endangering public safety, particularly for women, girls and school children who face harassment and experience fear while travelling.

Therefore, immediate action is needed to address those issues including investing in rehabilitation programmes, strengthening law enforcement and building community support systems to protect youth, women and children.
